ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None.
Had a mixture of lecture and breakout rooms/discussion
live virtual lecture + discussion in small groups & among the whole class

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about wetlands and various issues affecting them.

I learned about wetland development and formation, as well as problems facing contemporary wetlands and factors that affect wetland growth and stability. This includes issues like sedimentation, climate change, wetland productivity, and nutrient availability among others.
Wetlands from multiple angles - regulation, history, science, restoration, etc
I learned about wetlands from a scientific (ecological, biogeochemical, etc.) and a regulatory perspective.

I learned about:
1) what wetlands are
2) wetland classification systems
3) Wetland management
4) Ecosystems services
A much deeper understanding of wetlands and their significance to the environment.

Wetlands was a wonderful course! I am not a STEM major and was hesitant going into this course. The material is fascinating yet accessible! I had never known how ubiquitous and crucial wetlands truly are. A wonderful course, and it was structured well for learning!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lectures didn't always relate to the readings or feel relevant when combined with the readings.

This course had interesting readings and the best discussion was in small groups. Those were both strengths, and the willingness of all the instructors to engage with students was great. However, the full-class discussions were not as good as they could have been, because no one really contributed. The online discussion board was similarly not ideal; it worked successfully as a tool for forcing us to do readings but I don't think anyone really enjoyed making discussion posts and there wasn't much real back-and-forth on the forum. Perhaps these problems could be solved by decreasing the amount of comments necessary online but forcing students to defend their discussion posts in class. This would decrease the burden of posting online and ensure that the remaining comments are higher-effort while also creating a mechanism for student contributions.
I liked the lecture with a small amount of breakout rooms. The ~20-30 minute discussions were a nice amount of time and I thought they were actually useful and not just a way to spend time

I think the biggest strength of the course was that the readings were interesting and gave good insight into a lot of different aspects of wetland ecology, conservation, and management. I also think that because we were required to write a discussion post about the readings and reply to other posts every day before class, it forced people to actually read and engage with the texts. However, we were often expected to discuss the readings at length during class time, which resulted in one of two things. Either we were asked basic questions about the articles that felt pointless after having written a discussion post or we were told to have an open-ended conversation about the readings that usually fell flat because everyone had said what they already wanted to say on the discussion board. I personally would have appreciated more formal lectures because it felt like we exhausted the readings but there was still more to learn about the topics. A traditional lecture would have filled in those gaps in knowledge and also stimulated some more interesting discussion with new information.
This class was an entertaining lecture. Professor was very vibrant and engaged. Material was a bit dry sometimes. Overall, good class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Using the discussion board seemed like a good way to start discussions.

I personally disliked a lot of the games we played and shared docs we filled out because they felt like a waste of time on Zoom. It honestly felt like we were being treated like a middle school class rather than a group of college and graduate students.
Class was held virtually and professor was lenient with people taking it asynchronously.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would definitely recommend this course.

I would recommend this course to students who are interested in wetlands but don't have much broad theoretical knowledge about them. If you already have practical experience with wetlands in the field or extensive experience in certain types of wetlands, this class will feel repetitive at times. However, the material is interesting and the course is well-taught so anyone would benefit from taking this course.
Yes. I enjoyed how the class explored a specific ecosystem from multiple angles. I think it's a unique class for that reason

Yes. I think this course is particularly good for E&EB majors who want to learn some practical things about conservation/management or EVST majors who want to learn about ecology as the scientific underpinning for conservation/management/regulation decisions. Anyone else broadly interested in taking a deep dive into an interesting ecosystem would also enjoy this class.

Discussion posts for every class was excessive- everyone ended up writing like 400 words per post, meaning that for 2 classes a week, everyone was essentially writing a 3.5 page paper. Also, the TA's were a bit nit-picky with grading on the written p-sets. However, the TA's were really great, as well as the professor. As a science credit, definitely not a bad option.
Yes. Wetlands are a very fitting topic to focus on over the course of a semester because they are so diverse and can be approached from numerous angles (ecological, political, design-wise, etc.).

If you are interested in wetlands, absolutely! You get out what you put in with this class, so if you are truly interested in learning more, there is a lot of flexibility to help tailor each student's experience.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student! There is quite a bit of reading, but all of the articles are fascinating. This course was structured well for learning. I would recommend it to STEM and non-STEM students alike.
